title-group.article-title: TIPS, the Dual Duration, and the Pension Plan

abstract.p: By defining "duration" as the sensitivity of an asset's price to changes in some other variable, one may characterize any asset as having an inflation duration, $\text{D}_{i}$, and a real-interest-rate duration, $\text{D}_{r}$. Unlike nominal bonds, for which $\text{D}_{i}$=$\text{D}_{r}$, inflation-linked bonds, such as Treasurt Inflation-Indexed Securities (commonly called TIPS), have different values for $\text{D}_{i}$ and $\text{D}_{r}$. Defined-benefit pension liabilities also have different values for $\text{D}_{i}$ and $\text{D}_{r}$. Such liabilities can be modeled as bonds (or portfolios of bonds, and equities or other assets) held short. Thus, by appropriately combining TIPS and nominal bonds, a manager can build a portfolio that has the same inflation duration and real-interest-rate duration as the liability stream. Equities also have different values for $\text{D}_{i}$ and $\text{D}_{r}$, so the interaction of equities with TIPS and nominal bonds can be exploited in forming efficient pension portfolios--particularly in defeasing various liability streams.
